0.html: The ABI decoding submodule provides functionality for decoding Starknet contract data.
0.text: The ABI decoding submodule provides functionality for decoding Starknet contract data.
0.title: ABI Decoding

1.html: decoded, err := abi.DecodeFunctionCall(functionName, encodedData)
1.title: Decode Function Call

2.html: decoded, err := abi.DecodeConstructor(encodedData)
2.title: Decode Constructor

3.html: decoded, err := abi.DecodeEvent(eventName, encodedData)
3.title: Decode Event

4.html: decoded, err := abi.DecodeStruct(structName, encodedData)
4.title: Decode Struct

5.html: decoded, err := abi.DecodeArray(elementType, encodedData)
5.title: Decode Array

6.html:
// Decode a function call
decoded, err := abi.DecodeFunctionCall("transfer", encodedData)
if err != nil {
    log.Fatal(err)
}
recipient := decoded[0].(string)
amount := decoded[1].(string)
 
// Decode a constructor
decoded, err = abi.DecodeConstructor(encodedData)
if err != nil {
    log.Fatal(err)
}
name := decoded[0].(string)
symbol := decoded[1].(string)
decimals := decoded[2].(string)
 
// Decode an event
decoded, err = abi.DecodeEvent("Transfer", encodedData)
if err != nil {
    log.Fatal(err)
}
from := decoded[0].(string)
to := decoded[1].(string)
value := decoded[2].(string)
 
// Decode a struct
decoded, err = abi.DecodeStruct("Point", encodedData)
if err != nil {
    log.Fatal(err)
}
x := decoded["x"].(string)
y := decoded["y"].(string)
 
// Decode an array
decoded, err = abi.DecodeArray("felt", encodedData)
if err != nil {
    log.Fatal(err)
}
elements := decoded.([]string)
6.title: Example Usage

7.html: The ABI encoding submodule provides functionality for encoding Starknet contract data.
7.text: The ABI encoding submodule provides functionality for encoding Starknet contract data.
7.title: ABI Encoding

8.html: encoded, err := abi.EncodeFunctionCall(functionName, args)
8.title: Encode Function Call

9.html: encoded, err := abi.EncodeConstructor(args)
9.title: Encode Constructor

10.html: encoded, err := abi.EncodeEvent(eventName, args)
10.title: Encode Event

11.html: encoded, err := abi.EncodeStruct(structName, fields)
11.title: Encode Struct

12.html: encoded, err := abi.EncodeArray(elementType, elements)
12.title: Encode Array

13.html:
// Encode a function call
encoded, err := abi.EncodeFunctionCall("transfer", []interface{}{
    "0x123...", // recipient
    "1000",     // amount
})
if err != nil {
    log.Fatal(err)
}
 
// Encode a constructor
encoded, err = abi.EncodeConstructor([]interface{}{
    "MyToken",  // name
    "MTK",      // symbol
    "18",       // decimals
})
if err != nil {
    log.Fatal(err)
}
 
// Encode an event
encoded, err = abi.EncodeEvent("Transfer", []interface{}{
    "0x123...", // from
    "0x456...", // to
    "1000",     // value
})
if err != nil {
    log.Fatal(err)
}
 
// Encode a struct
encoded, err = abi.EncodeStruct("Point", map[string]interface{}{
    "x": "100",
    "y": "200",
})
if err != nil {
    log.Fatal(err)
}
 
// Encode an array
encoded, err = abi.EncodeArray("felt", []interface{}{
    "1", "2", "3", "4", "5",
})
if err != nil {
    log.Fatal(err)
}
13.title: Example Usage

19.html: The account management submodule provides core functionality for creating and managing Starknet accounts.
19.text: The account management submodule provides core functionality for creating and managing Starknet accounts.
19.title: Account Management

20.html:
An account in Starknet.go is represented by the Account struct, which contains:

  • Public key
  • Private key
  • Address
  • Chain ID
  • Provider interface
20.text:
An account in Starknet.go is represented by the Account struct, which contains:

Public key
Private key
Address
Chain ID
Provider interface
20.title: Account Structure

21.html:
To create a new account:


account, err := account.NewAccount(privateKey, address, chainID, provider) 
if err != nil {
    // Handle error
}
21.title: Creating an Account

23.html:
Sign a transaction or message:


signature, err := account.Sign(message) 
if err != nil {
    // Handle error
}
23.title: Sign

24.html:
Verify a signature:

isValid := account.Verify(message, signature)
24.text:
Verify a signature:
isValid := account.Verify(message, signature)
24.title: Verify

25.html:
Get the account's address:

address := account.GetAddress()
25.text:
Get the account's address:
address := account.GetAddress()
25.title: GetAddress

26.html:
// Create a new account
privateKey := "0x123..." // Your private key
address := "0x456..."    // Your account address
chainID := "SN_MAIN"     // Starknet chain ID
provider := // Your provider implementation
 

account, err := account.NewAccount(privateKey, address, chainID, provider) 
if err != nil {
    log.Fatal(err)
}
 
// Sign a message
message := []byte("Hello, Starknet!") 
signature, err := account.Sign(message) 
if err != nil {
    log.Fatal(err)
}
 
// Verify the signature
isValid := account.Verify(message, signature) 
fmt.Printf("Signature valid: %v\n", isValid)
26.title: Example Usage

27.html: The account utilities submodule provides helper functions and utilities for working with Starknet accounts.
27.text: The account utilities submodule provides helper functions and utilities for working with Starknet accounts.
27.title: Account Utilities

29.html: isValid := account.ValidateAddress(address)
29.title: Address Validation

30.html: publicKey := account.GeneratePublicKey(privateKey)
30.title: Public Key Generation

31.html: address := account.GenerateAddress(publicKey)
31.title: Address Generation

32.html: isValid := account.ValidateChainID(chainID)
32.title: Chain ID Validation

33.html:
// Validate an address 
address := "0x123..."
isValid := account.ValidateAddress(address) 
fmt.Printf("Address valid: %v\n", isValid) 
 
// Generate public key from private key 
privateKey := "0x456..."
publicKey := account.GeneratePublicKey(privateKey) 
fmt.Printf("Public key: %s\n", publicKey) 
 
// Generate address from public key 
address = account.GenerateAddress(publicKey) 
fmt.Printf("Generated address: %s\n", address) 
 
// Validate chain ID 
chainID := "SN_MAIN"
isValid = account.ValidateChainID(chainID) 
fmt.Printf("Chain ID valid: %v\n", isValid)
33.title: Example Usage

35.html:
// Encode bytes to hex
hex := account.EncodeHex(bytes)
 
// Decode hex to bytes
bytes, err := account.DecodeHex(hex)
35.title: Hex Encoding/Decoding

36.html:
// Convert to field element
fe := account.ToFieldElement(value)
 
// Convert from field element
value := account.FromFieldElement(fe)
36.title: Field Element Conversion

37.html:
// Check for specific errors
if err != nil {
    if account.IsInvalidAddressError(err) {
        // Handle invalid address error
    } else if account.IsInvalidSignatureError(err) {
        // Handle invalid signature error
    }
}
37.title: Error Handling

43.html: The signature verification submodule provides functionality for verifying signatures in Starknet.
43.text: The signature verification submodule provides functionality for verifying signatures in Starknet.
43.title: Signature Verification

44.html:
The package supports various signature types:

  • ECDSA signatures
  • Pedersen hash signatures
  • Stark signatures
44.text:
The package supports various signature types:

ECDSA signatures
Pedersen hash signatures
Stark signatures
44.title: Signature Types

46.html: isValid := account.VerifyECDSASignature(message, signature, publicKey)
46.title: Verify ECDSA Signature

47.html: isValid := account.VerifyPedersenSignature(message, signature, publicKey)
47.title: Verify Pedersen Signature

48.html: isValid := account.VerifyStarkSignature(message, signature, publicKey)
48.title: Verify Stark Signature

49.html:
// Example message and signature 
message := []byte("Hello, Starknet!") 
signature := "0x123..." // Your signature 
publicKey := "0x456..." // Your public key 
 
// Verify ECDSA signature 
isValid := account.VerifyECDSASignature(message, signature, publicKey) 
fmt.Printf("ECDSA Signature valid: %v\n", isValid) 
 
// Verify Pedersen signature 
isValid = account.VerifyPedersenSignature(message, signature, publicKey) 
fmt.Printf("Pedersen Signature valid: %v\n", isValid) 
 
// Verify Stark signature 
isValid = account.VerifyStarkSignature(message, signature, publicKey) 
fmt.Printf("Stark Signature valid: %v\n", isValid)
49.title: Example Usage

50.html:
Signatures in Starknet are typically represented as:

  • ECDSA: (r, s) pair
  • Pedersen: (r, s) pair
  • Stark: (r, s) pair

Where:

  • r and s are field elements
  • Each element is represented as a hex string
  • The signature is typically concatenated as r + s
50.text:
Signatures in Starknet are typically represented as:

ECDSA: (r, s) pair
Pedersen: (r, s) pair
Stark: (r, s) pair

Where:

r and s are field elements
Each element is represented as a hex string
The signature is typically concatenated as r + s
50.title: Signature Format

51.html: The transaction handling submodule provides functionality for creating, signing, and sending transactions on Starknet.
51.text: The transaction handling submodule provides functionality for creating, signing, and sending transactions on Starknet.
51.title: Transaction Handling

52.html:
The package supports various transaction types:

  • Invoke transactions
  • Deploy transactions
  • Declare transactions
52.text:
The package supports various transaction types:

Invoke transactions
Deploy transactions
Declare transactions
52.title: Transaction Types

54.html:
tx := account.NewInvokeTransaction(
    contractAddress,
    entryPointSelector,
    calldata,
    maxFee,
    version,
    nonce,
)
54.text:
tx := account.NewInvokeTransaction(
    contractAddress,
    entryPointSelector,
    calldata,
    maxFee,
    version,
    nonce,
)
54.title: Invoke Transaction

55.html:
tx := account.NewDeployTransaction(
    contractClassHash,
    constructorCalldata,
    salt,
    version,
)
55.text:

    contractClassHash,
    constructorCalldata,
    salt,
    version,
)
55.title: Deploy Transaction

57.html:
signedTx, err := account.SignTransaction(tx) 
if err != nil {
    // Handle error
}
57.title: Sign Transaction

58.html:
txHash, err := account.SendTransaction(signedTx) 
if err != nil {
    // Handle error
}
58.title: Send Transaction

59.html:
receipt, err := account.WaitForTransaction(txHash) 
if err != nil {
    // Handle error
}
59.title: Wait for Transaction

60.html:
// Create an invoke transaction 
tx := account.NewInvokeTransaction( 
    "0x123...", // contract address 
    "0x456...", // entry point selector 
    []string{"0x789..."}, // calldata 
    "1000000000000000", // max fee 
    "0x1", // version 
    "0x1", // nonce 
) 
 
// Sign the transaction 
signedTx, err := account.SignTransaction(tx) 
if err != nil {
    log.Fatal(err)
}
 
// Send the transaction 
txHash, err := account.SendTransaction(signedTx) 
if err != nil {
    log.Fatal(err)
}
 
// Wait for transaction confirmation 
receipt, err := account.WaitForTransaction(txHash) 
if err != nil {
    log.Fatal(err)
}
 
fmt.Printf("Transaction confirmed with status: %s\n", receipt.Status)
60.title: Example Usage

66.html: The curve operations submodule provides functionality for performing operations on curves in Starknet.
66.text: The curve operations submodule provides functionality for performing operations on curves in Starknet.
66.title: Curve Operations

68.html: result := curve.Add(point1, point2)
68.title: Point Addition

69.html: result := curve.Mul(point, scalar)
69.title: Point Multiplication

70.html: result := curve.Double(point)
70.title: Point Doubling

71.html: result := curve.Neg(point)
71.title: Point Negation

73.html: result := curve.FieldAdd(a, b)
73.title: Field Addition

74.html: result := curve.FieldMul(a, b)
74.title: Field Multiplication

75.html: result := curve.FieldDiv(a, b)
75.title: Field Division

76.html: result := curve.FieldInv(a)
76.title: Field Inversion

78.html: order := curve.Order()
78.title: Curve Order

79.html: generator := curve.Generator()
79.title: Curve Generator

80.html: isOnCurve := curve.IsOnCurve(point)
80.title: Curve Is On Curve

81.html: isValid := curve.IsValid(point)
81.title: Curve Is Valid

82.html:
// Create a curve
curve := curves.NewStarkCurve()
 
// Add two points
result := curve.Add(point1, point2)
 
// Multiply a point by a scalar
result := curve.Mul(point, scalar)
 
// Double a point
result := curve.Double(point)
 
// Negate a point
result := curve.Neg(point)
 
// Add two field elements
result := curve.FieldAdd(a, b)
 
// Multiply two field elements
result := curve.FieldMul(a, b)
 
// Divide two field elements
result := curve.FieldDiv(a, b)
 
// Invert a field element
result := curve.FieldInv(a)
 
// Get the curve order
order := curve.Order()
 
// Get the curve generator
generator := curve.Generator()
 
// Check if a point is on the curve
isOnCurve := curve.IsOnCurve(point)
 
// Check if a point is valid
isValid := curve.IsValid(point)
82.title: Example Usage

83.html: The curve types submodule provides functionality for working with different types of curves in Starknet.

84.html:
The package supports various curve types:

  • Stark curve
  • Pedersen curve
  • ECDSA curve
84.text:
The package supports various curve types:

Stark curve
Pedersen curve
ECDSA curve
84.title: Curve Types

85.html:
The Stark curve is the main curve used in Starknet. It is defined by the equation:

y = x + x +

Where:

  • and are constants
  • The curve is defined over a prime field
85.text:
The Stark curve is the main curve used in Starknet. It is defined by the equation:
y = x + x + 
Where:

 and  are constants
The curve is defined over a prime field
85.title: Stark Curve

86.html: curve := curves.NewStarkCurve()
86.title: Creating a Stark Curve

87.html:
// Add two points
result := curve.Add(point1, point2)
 
// Multiply a point by a scalar
result := curve.Mul(point, scalar)
 
// Get the generator point
generator := curve.Generator()
87.title: Stark Curve Operations

The Pedersen curve is used for Pedersen hashing in Starknet. It is defined by the equation:

y = x + x +

93.html:
// Add two points
result := curve.Add(point1, point2)
 
// Multiply a point by a scalar

93.title: ECDSA Curve Operations

94.html:
// Create a Stark curve
starkCurve := curves.NewStarkCurve()
 
// Create a Pedersen curve
pedersenCurve := curves.NewPedersenCurve()
 
// Create an ECDSA curve
ecdsaCurve := curves.NewECDSACurve()
 
// Add two points on the Stark curve
result := starkCurve.Add(point1, point2)
 
// Multiply a point by a scalar on the Pedersen curve
result := pedersenCurve.Mul(point, scalar)
 
// Get the generator point on the ECDSA curve
generator := ecdsaCurve.Generator()
94.title: Example Usage

95.html: We welcome contributions from the community! This guide will help you get started with contributing to Starknet.go.
95.text: We welcome contributions from the community! This guide will help you get started with contributing to Starknet.go.

96.html: Please read and follow our Code of Conduct to keep our community approachable and respectable.
96.text: Please read and follow our Code of Conduct to keep our community approachable and respectable.

97.html:
There are many ways to contribute to Starknet.go:

  • Reporting bugs
  • Suggesting enhancements
  • Improving documentation
  • Submitting pull requests
97.text:
There are many ways to contribute to Starknet.go:

Reporting bugs
Suggesting enhancements
Improving documentation
Submitting pull requests
97.title: How to Contribute

98.html:
If you find a bug, please create an issue on our GitHub repository with:

  • A clear title and description
  • As much relevant information as possible
  • A code sample or test case demonstrating the bug
98.text:
If you find a bug, please create an issue on our GitHub repository with:

A clear title and description
As much relevant information as possible
A code sample or test case demonstrating the bug
98.title: Reporting Bugs

99.html:
Enhancement suggestions are also welcome. Please create an issue with:

  • A clear title and description
  • A detailed explanation of the proposed functionality
  • Any relevant examples or use cases

  • Fix typos or clarify existing documentation
  • Add examples or tutorials

101.html:
1. Fork the repository
  2. Create a new branch (git checkout -b feature/amazing-feature)
  3. Make your changes
  4. Run tests to ensure they pass
  5. Commit your changes (git commit -m 'Add some amazing feature')
  6. Push to the branch (git push origin feature/amazing-feature)
  7. Open a Pull Request
101.text:
Fork the repository
Create a new branch (git checkout -b feature/amazing-feature)
Make your changes
Run tests to ensure they pass
Commit your changes (git commit -m 'Add some amazing feature')
Push to the branch (git push origin feature/amazing-feature)
Open a Pull Request
101.title: Pull Requests

104.html:
1. Clone your fork of the repository:

    git clone https://github.com/yourusername/starknet.go.git
cd starknet.go

  2. Add the original repository as an upstream remote:

    git remote add upstream https://github.com/NethermindEth/starknet.go.git

  3. Install dependencies:

    go mod download
104.text:

git clone https://github.com/yourusername/starknet.go.git
cd starknet.go


Add the original repository as an upstream remote:
git remote add upstream https://github.com/NethermindEth/starknet.go.git


Install dependencies:

106.html: This guide will help you start using Starknet.go in your Go project. We'll walk through a simple example to demonstrate how to connect to Starknet and perform basic operations.
106.text: This guide will help you start using Starknet.go in your Go project. We'll walk through a simple example to demonstrate how to connect to Starknet and perform basic operations.
106.title: Get started

107.html:
Before you begin, make sure you have:

  • Installed Go 1.20 or higher
  • Installed Starknet.go
  • Basic understanding of Go programming
107.text:
Before you begin, make sure you have:

Installed Go 1.20 or higher
Installed Starknet.go
Basic understanding of Go programming
107.title: Prerequisites

108.html: Let's create a simple application that connects to Starknet and retrieves the latest block number.
108.text: Let's create a simple application that connects to Starknet and retrieves the latest block number.
108.title: Creating Your First Starknet.go Application

109.html:
Create a new directory for your project and initialize a Go module:

mkdir my-starknet-app
cd my-starknet-app
go mod init my-starknet-app
109.text:
Create a new directory for your project and initialize a Go module:
mkdir my-starknet-app
cd my-starknet-app
go mod init my-starknet-app
109.title: Step 1: Set up your project

110.html:
Add Starknet.go to your project:

go get github.com/NethermindEth/starknet.go
110.text:
Add Starknet.go to your project:
go get github.com/NethermindEth/starknet.go
110.title: Step 2: Install dependencies

111.html:
Create a new file main.go with the following code:

package main
 
import (
    "context"
    "fmt"
    "log"
 
    "github.com/NethermindEth/starknet.go/rpc"
)
 
func main() {
    // Initialize connection to RPC provider
    // Replace with your preferred Starknet node URL
    client, err := rpc.NewProvider("https://your-starknet-node-url")
    if err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }
 
    fmt.Println("Established connection with the client")
 
    // Get the latest block number
    blockNumber, err := client.BlockNumber(context.Background())
    if err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }
 
    fmt.Printf("Latest block number: %d\n", blockNumber)
}
111.title: Step 3: Create the main application

112.html:
Run your application:

go run main.go

You should see output similar to:

Established connection with the client
Latest block number: 123456
112.text:
Run your application:
go run main.go
You should see output similar to:
Established connection with the client
Latest block number: 123456
112.title: Step 4: Run the application

113.html:
Now that you have a basic application working, you can explore more features:

  1. Client Configuration - Learn how to configure your Starknet client
  2. Client Methods - Explore available methods for interacting with Starknet
  3. Examples - See more examples of using Starknet.go
113.text:
Now that you have a basic application working, you can explore more features:

Client Configuration - Learn how to configure your Starknet client
Client Methods - Explore available methods for interacting with Starknet
Examples - See more examples of using Starknet.go
113.title: Next Steps

114.html:
If you encounter any issues:

  1. Make sure your Starknet node URL is correct and accessible
  2. Check that you have the latest version of Starknet.go installed
  3. Verify your Go version meets the minimum requirement (1.20 or higher)
  4. Check the documentation for more detailed setup instructions
114.text:
If you encounter any issues:

Make sure your Starknet node URL is correct and accessible
Check that you have the latest version of Starknet.go installed
Verify your Go version meets the minimum requirement (1.20 or higher)
Check the documentation for more detailed setup instructions
114.title: Troubleshooting

115.html: Starknet.go is a Go library for interacting with the Starknet blockchain. This guide will help you set up Starknet.go in your Go project.
115.text: Starknet.go is a Go library for interacting with the Starknet blockchain. This guide will help you set up Starknet.go in your Go project.
115.title: Installation

116.html:
• Go 1.20 or higher
  • Basic familiarity with Go modules
116.text:
Go 1.20 or higher
Basic familiarity with Go modules
116.title: Prerequisites

117.html: You can install Starknet.go using the go get command:
117.text: You can install Starknet.go using the go get command:
117.title: Installing the Package

118.html: Starknet.go is a Go library that provides a simple and efficient way to interact with the Starknet blockchain. It is designed to be easy to use, well-documented, and performant.
118.text: Starknet.go is a Go library that provides a simple and efficient way to interact with the Starknet blockchain. It is designed to be easy to use, well-documented, and performant.
118.title: Why Starknet.go?

119.html:
• Complete Starknet API Coverage: Full implementation of Starknet RPC v0.8.0 spec, including:
    • Block and transaction operations
    • State and storage queries
    • Contract interactions
    • Event subscriptions
    • Transaction simulation and tracing
  • WebSocket Support: Real-time updates through WebSocket subscriptions for:
    • Events
    • New block headers
    • Pending transactions
    • Transaction status updates
  • Type Safety: Leverage Go's strong typing for safer contract interactions
  • Performance: Built with efficiency in mind for high-throughput applications
  • Easy Integration: Simple to incorporate into existing Go applications
  • Well-Documented: Comprehensive documentation and examples
  • Community Support: Active development and responsive community
119.text:
Complete Starknet API Coverage: Full implementation of Starknet RPC v0.8.0 spec, including:

Block and transaction operations
State and storage queries
Contract interactions
Event subscriptions
Transaction simulation and tracing


WebSocket Support: Real-time updates through WebSocket subscriptions for:

Events
New block headers
Pending transactions
Transaction status updates


Type Safety: Leverage Go's strong typing for safer contract interactions
Performance: Built with efficiency in mind for high-throughput applications
Easy Integration: Simple to incorporate into existing Go applications
Well-Documented: Comprehensive documentation and examples
Community Support: Active development and responsive community
119.title: Features

120.html:
Starknet.go is ideal for:

  • Building backend services that interact with Starknet
  • Developing tools for Starknet blockchain analysis
  • Creating automated trading or DeFi applications
  • Implementing wallet functionality in Go applications
  • Integrating Starknet capabilities into existing Go infrastructure
  • Building real-time monitoring and analytics tools
  • Developing automated testing and deployment pipelines
120.text:
Starknet.go is ideal for:

Building backend services that interact with Starknet
Developing tools for Starknet blockchain analysis
Creating automated trading or DeFi applications
Implementing wallet functionality in Go applications
Integrating Starknet capabilities into existing Go infrastructure
Building real-time monitoring and analytics tools
Developing automated testing and deployment pipelines

122.html:
The library includes several example applications to help you get started:

  • Simple Contract Calls: Basic contract interaction examples
  • Account Deployment: Deploy new account contracts on testnet
  • Transaction Invocation: Add new invoke transactions
  • Contract Declaration: Add new contracts to the network
  • UDC Deployment: Deploy contracts using Universal Deployer Contract
  • Typed Data: Sign and verify typed data
  • WebSocket Integration: Subscribe to real-time updates

125.html: The RPC examples submodule provides examples of how to use the Starknet RPC.
125.text: The RPC examples submodule provides examples of how to use the Starknet RPC.
125.title: RPC Examples

127.html:
package main
 
import (
    "fmt"
    "log"
 
    "github.com/NethermindEth/starknet.go/rpc"
)
 
func main() {
    // Get a block by number
    block, err := rpc.GetBlockByNumber(1)
    if err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }
 
    fmt.Printf("Block hash: %s\n", block.Hash)
    fmt.Printf("Block number: %d\n", block.Number)
    fmt.Printf("Block timestamp: %d\n", block.Timestamp)
}
127.title: Getting a Block

128.html:
package main
 
import (
    "fmt"
    "log"
 
    "github.com/NethermindEth/starknet.go/rpc"
)
 
func main() {
    // Get a transaction by hash
    tx, err := rpc.GetTransactionByHash("0x123...")
    if err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }
 
    fmt.Printf("Transaction type: %s\n", tx.Type)
    fmt.Printf("Transaction status: %s\n", tx.Status)
    fmt.Printf("Transaction hash: %s\n", tx.Hash)
}
128.title: Getting a Transaction

130.html:
package main
 
import (
    "fmt"
    "log"
 
    "github.com/NethermindEth/starknet.go/rpc"
)
 
func main() {
    // Create a transaction
    tx := rpc.NewTransaction(
        "0x456...", // contract address
        "0x789...", // entry point selector
        []string{"0xabc..."}, // calldata
        "1000000000000000", // max fee
        "0x1", // version
        "0x1", // nonce
    )
 
    // Send the transaction
    txHash, err := rpc.SendTransaction(tx)
    if err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }
 
    fmt.Printf("Transaction sent with hash: %s\n", txHash)
}
130.title: Sending a Transaction

131.html:
package main
 
import (
    "fmt"
    "log"
 
    "github.com/NethermindEth/starknet.go/rpc"
)
 
func main() {
    // Call a contract
    result, err := rpc.CallContract(
        "0x456...", // contract address
        "0x789...", // entry point selector
        []string{"0xabc..."}, // calldata
    )
    if err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }
 
    fmt.Printf("Call result: %s\n", result)
}
131.title: Calling a Contract

132.html:
package main
 
import (
    "fmt"
    "log"
 
    "github.com/NethermindEth/starknet.go/rpc"
)
 
func main() {
    // Get contract storage
    storage, err := rpc.GetContractStorage(
        "0x456...", // contract address
        "0x789...", // key
    )
    if err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }
 
    fmt.Printf("Storage value: %s\n", storage)
}
132.title: Getting Contract Storage

  • Devnet setup

Devnet usage
Devnet utilities

155.html:
To use the Devnet package, import it in your Go code:

import "github.com/NethermindEth/starknet.go/devnet"

157.html: The devnet setup submodule provides functionality for setting up Starknet development networks.
157.text: The devnet setup submodule provides functionality for setting up Starknet development networks.
157.title: Devnet Setup

158.html:
The devnet configuration is represented by the DevnetConfig struct, which contains:

  • Network name
  • Network ID
  • Chain ID
  • Genesis block
  • Genesis accounts
  • Genesis contracts
158.text:
The devnet configuration is represented by the DevnetConfig struct, which contains:

Network name
Network ID
Chain ID
Genesis block
Genesis accounts
Genesis contracts
158.title: Devnet Configuration

159.html:
To create a new devnet:

config := devnet.DevnetConfig{
    NetworkName: "local",
    NetworkID: 1,
    ChainID: "SN_DEV",
    GenesisBlock: devnet.GenesisBlock{
        Timestamp: time.Now().Unix(),
        GasLimit: 1000000,
    },
    GenesisAccounts: []devnet.GenesisAccount{
        {
            Address: "0x123...",
            Balance: "1000000000000000000",
        },
    },
    GenesisContracts: []devnet.GenesisContract{
        {
            Address: "0x456...",
            Code: "0x789...",
        },
    },
}
 
devnet, err := devnet.NewDevnet(config)
if err != nil {
    // Handle error
}
159.title: Creating a Devnet

161.html:
The network name is the name of the devnet:

config.NetworkName = "local"
161.text:
The network name is the name of the devnet:
config.NetworkName = "local"
161.title: Network Name

162.html:
The network ID is the ID of the devnet:

config.NetworkID = 1
162.text:
The network ID is the ID of the devnet:
config.NetworkID = 1
162.title: Network ID

163.html:
The chain ID is the ID of the chain:

config.ChainID = "SN_DEV"
163.text:
The chain ID is the ID of the chain:
config.ChainID = "SN_DEV"
163.title: Chain ID

164.html:
The genesis block is the first block of the devnet:

config.GenesisBlock = devnet.GenesisBlock{
    Timestamp: time.Now().Unix(),
    GasLimit: 1000000,
}
164.title: Genesis Block

165.html:
The genesis accounts are the initial accounts of the devnet:

config.GenesisAccounts = []devnet.GenesisAccount{
    {
        Address: "0x123...",
        Balance: "1000000000000000000",
    },
}
165.title: Genesis Accounts

166.html:
The genesis contracts are the initial contracts of the devnet:

config.GenesisContracts = []devnet.GenesisContract{
    {
        Address: "0x456...",
        Code: "0x789...",
    },
}
166.title: Genesis Contracts

167.html:
// Create a new devnet
config := devnet.DevnetConfig{
    NetworkName: "local",
    NetworkID: 1,
    ChainID: "SN_DEV",
    GenesisBlock: devnet.GenesisBlock{
        Timestamp: time.Now().Unix(),
        GasLimit: 1000000,
    },
    GenesisAccounts: []devnet.GenesisAccount{
        {
            Address: "0x123...",
            Balance: "1000000000000000000",
        },
    },
    GenesisContracts: []devnet.GenesisContract{
        {
            Address: "0x456...",
            Code: "0x789...",
        },
    },
}
 
devnet, err := devnet.NewDevnet(config)
if err != nil {
    log.Fatal(err)
}
 
// Start the devnet
err = devnet.Start()
if err != nil {
    log.Fatal(err)
}
 
// Stop the devnet
err = devnet.Stop()
if err != nil {
    log.Fatal(err)
}
167.title: Example Usage

168.html: The devnet usage submodule provides functionality for using Starknet development networks.
168.text: The devnet usage submodule provides functionality for using Starknet development networks.
168.title: Devnet Usage

170.html:
err := devnet.Start()
if err != nil {
    // Handle error
}
170.title: Start Devnet

171.html:
err := devnet.Stop()
if err != nil {
    // Handle error
}
171.title: Stop Devnet

172.html:
err := devnet.Reset()
if err != nil {
    // Handle error
}
172.title: Reset Devnet

173.html: status := devnet.GetStatus()
173.title: Get Devnet Status

174.html: accounts := devnet.GetAccounts()
174.title: Get Devnet Accounts

175.html: contracts := devnet.GetContracts()
175.title: Get Devnet Contracts

176.html:
// Create a new devnet
devnet, err := devnet.NewDevnet(devnet.DevnetConfig{
    NetworkName: "local",
    NetworkID: 1,
    ChainID: "SN_DEV",
})
if err != nil {
    log.Fatal(err)
}
 
// Start the devnet
err = devnet.Start()
if err != nil {
    log.Fatal(err)
}
 
// Get the devnet status
status := devnet.GetStatus()
fmt.Printf("Devnet status: %s\n", status)
 
// Get the devnet accounts
accounts := devnet.GetAccounts()
for _, account := range accounts {
    fmt.Printf("Account address: %s\n", account.Address)
    fmt.Printf("Account balance: %s\n", account.Balance)
}
 
// Get the devnet contracts
contracts := devnet.GetContracts()
for _, contract := range contracts {
    fmt.Printf("Contract address: %s\n", contract.Address)
    fmt.Printf("Contract code: %s\n", contract.Code)
}
 
// Reset the devnet
err = devnet.Reset()
if err != nil {
    log.Fatal(err)
}
 
// Stop the devnet
err = devnet.Stop()
if err != nil {
    log.Fatal(err)
}
176.title: Example Usage

177.html: The client configuration submodule provides functionality for configuring Starknet clients.
177.text: The client configuration submodule provides functionality for configuring Starknet clients.
177.title: Client Configuration

178.html:
The client configuration is represented by the ClientConfig struct, which contains:

  • Node URL
  • Chain ID
  • Timeout
  • Retry configuration
  • Logging configuration
178.text:
The client configuration is represented by the ClientConfig struct, which contains:

Node URL
Chain ID
Timeout
Retry configuration
Logging configuration
178.title: Client Configuration

179.html:
To create a new client:

config := client.ClientConfig{
    NodeURL: "https://your-node-url",
    ChainID: "SN_MAIN",
    Timeout: 30 * time.Second,
}
 
client, err := client.NewClient(config)
if err != nil {
    // Handle error
}
179.title: Creating a Client

181.html:
The node URL is the URL of the Starknet node to connect to:

config.NodeURL = "https://your-node-url"
181.text:
The node URL is the URL of the Starknet node to connect to:
config.NodeURL = "https://your-node-url"
181.title: Node URL

182.html:
The chain ID is the ID of the Starknet chain to connect to:

config.ChainID = "SN_MAIN"
182.text:
The chain ID is the ID of the Starknet chain to connect to:
config.ChainID = "SN_MAIN"
182.title: Chain ID

183.html:
The timeout is the maximum time to wait for a response:

config.Timeout = 30 * time.Second
183.text:
The timeout is the maximum time to wait for a response:
config.Timeout = 30 * time.Second
183.title: Timeout

184.html:
The retry configuration is used to configure retry behavior:

config.RetryConfig = client.RetryConfig{
    MaxRetries: 3,
    RetryDelay: 1 * time.Second,
}
184.title: Retry Configuration

185.html:
The logging configuration is used to configure logging behavior:

config.LoggingConfig = client.LoggingConfig{
    Level: "info",
    Format: "json",
}
185.title: Logging Configuration

186.html:
// Create a new client
config := client.ClientConfig{
    NodeURL: "https://your-node-url",
    ChainID: "SN_MAIN",
    Timeout: 30 * time.Second,
    RetryConfig: client.RetryConfig{
        MaxRetries: 3,
        RetryDelay: 1 * time.Second,
    },
    LoggingConfig: client.LoggingConfig{
        Level: "info",
        Format: "json",
    },
}
 
client, err := client.NewClient(config)
if err != nil {
    log.Fatal(err)
}
 
// Use the client
block, err := client.GetBlockByNumber(1)
if err != nil {
    log.Fatal(err)
}
 
fmt.Printf("Block hash: %s\n", block.Hash)
186.title: Example Usage

187.html: The client examples submodule provides examples of how to use the Starknet client.
187.text: The client examples submodule provides examples of how to use the Starknet client.
187.title: Client Examples

189.html:
package main
 
import (
    "fmt"
    "log"
    "time"
 
    "github.com/NethermindEth/starknet.go/client"
)
 
func main() {
    // Create a new client
    config := client.ClientConfig{
        NodeURL: "https://your-node-url",
        ChainID: "SN_MAIN",
        Timeout: 30 * time.Second,
    }
 
    client, err := client.NewClient(config)
    if err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }
 
    // Get the latest block
    block, err := client.GetLatestBlock()
    if err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }
 
    fmt.Printf("Latest block number: %d\n", block.Number)
}
189.title: Creating a Client

190.html:
package main
 
import (
    "fmt"
    "log"
 
    "github.com/NethermindEth/starknet.go/client"
)
 
func main() {
    // Create a new client
    client, err := client.NewClient(client.ClientConfig{
        NodeURL: "https://your-node-url",
        ChainID: "SN_MAIN",
    })
    if err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }
 
    // Get a block by number
    block, err := client.GetBlockByNumber(1)
    if err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }
 
    fmt.Printf("Block hash: %s\n", block.Hash)
    fmt.Printf("Block number: %d\n", block.Number)
    fmt.Printf("Block timestamp: %d\n", block.Timestamp)
}
190.title: Getting a Block

203.title: Get Block by Hash

204.html:
block, err := client.GetLatestBlock() 
if err != nil {
    // Handle error
}
204.title: Get Latest Block

206.html:
tx, err := client.GetTransactionByHash(txHash) 
if err != nil {
    // Handle error
}
206.title: Get Transaction by Hash

207.html:
receipt, err := client.GetTransactionReceipt(txHash) 
if err != nil {
    // Handle error
}
207.title: Get Transaction Receipt

208.html:
txHash, err := client.SendTransaction(tx) 
if err != nil {
    // Handle error
}
208.title: Send Transaction

210.html:
code, err := client.GetContractCode(contractAddress)
if err != nil {
    // Handle error
}
210.title: Get Contract Code

211.html:
storage, err := client.GetContractStorage(contractAddress, key)
if err != nil {
    // Handle error
}
211.title: Get Contract Storage

212.html:
result, err := client.CallContract(contractAddress, entryPointSelector, calldata)
if err != nil {
    // Handle error
}
212.title: Call Contract

213.html:
// Get the latest block 
block, err := client.GetLatestBlock() 
if err != nil {
    log.Fatal(err)
}
 
fmt.Printf("Latest block number: %d\n", block.Number) 
fmt.Printf("Latest block hash: %s\n", block.Hash) 
 
// Get a transaction 
tx, err := client.GetTransactionByHash("0x123...") 
if err != nil {
    log.Fatal(err)
}
 
fmt.Printf("Transaction type: %s\n", tx.Type) 
fmt.Printf("Transaction status: %s\n", tx.Status) 
 
// Call a contract 
result, err := client.CallContract( 
    "0x456...", // contract address 
    "0x789...", // entry point selector 
    []string{"0xabc..."}, // calldata 
)
if err != nil {
    log.Fatal(err)
}
 
fmt.Printf("Call result: %s\n", result)
213.title: Example Usage

214.html: The common utilities submodule provides functionality for common operations in Starknet.
214.text: The common utilities submodule provides functionality for common operations in Starknet.
214.title: Common Utilities

216.html: hex := utils.EncodeHex(bytes)
216.title: Encode Hex

217.html: bytes, err := utils.DecodeHex(hex)
217.title: Decode Hex

219.html: fe := utils.ToFieldElement(value)
219.title: To Field Element

220.html: value := utils.FromFieldElement(fe)
220.title: From Field Element

222.html: isValid := utils.ValidateAddress(address)
222.title: Validate Address

223.html: normalized := utils.NormalizeAddress(address)
223.title: Normalize Address

225.html: isValid := utils.ValidateChainID(chainID)
225.title: Validate Chain ID

226.html: chainID := utils.GetChainID()
226.title: Get Chain ID

228.html: isInvalid := utils.IsInvalidAddressError(err)
228.title: Is Invalid Address Error

229.html: isInvalid := utils.IsInvalidSignatureError(err)
229.title: Is Invalid Signature Error

230.html:
// Encode bytes to hex
hex := utils.EncodeHex([]byte("Hello, Starknet!"))
 
// Decode hex to bytes
bytes, err := utils.DecodeHex(hex)
if err != nil {
    log.Fatal(err)
}
 
// Convert to field element
fe := utils.ToFieldElement("123")
 
// Convert from field element
value := utils.FromFieldElement(fe)
 
// Validate address
isValid := utils.ValidateAddress("0x123...")
 
// Normalize address
normalized := utils.NormalizeAddress("0x123...")
 
// Validate chain ID
isValid = utils.ValidateChainID("SN_MAIN")
 
// Get chain ID
chainID := utils.GetChainID()
 
// Check for specific errors
if err != nil {
    if utils.IsInvalidAddressError(err) {
        // Handle invalid address error
    } else if utils.IsInvalidSignatureError(err) {
        // Handle invalid signature error
    }
}
230.title: Example Usage

231.html: The Utilities package provides common utility functions and helpers for working with Starknet. This package contains various components and utilities for common operations.
231.text: The Utilities package provides common utility functions and helpers for working with Starknet. This package contains various components and utilities for common operations.
231.title: Utilities Package

232.html:
The Utilities package includes:

  • Common utilities
  • Type utilities
  • Conversion utilities
232.text:
The Utilities package includes:

Common utilities
Type utilities
Conversion utilities
232.title: Overview

234.html:
To use the Utilities package, import it in your Go code:

import "github.com/NethermindEth/starknet.go/utils"
234.text:
To use the Utilities package, import it in your Go code:
import "github.com/NethermindEth/starknet.go/utils"
234.title: Getting Started

235.html: This documentation is based on version v0.8.1 of the Starknet.go library.
235.text: This documentation is based on version v0.8.1 of the Starknet.go library.
235.title: Version

236.html: The type utilities submodule provides functionality for working with Starknet types.
236.text: The type utilities submodule provides functionality for working with Starknet types.
236.title: Type Utilities

238.html: bigInt := utils.ToBigInt(value)
238.title: To Big Int

239.html: value := utils.FromBigInt(bigInt)
239.title: From Big Int

240.html: felt := utils.ToFelt(value)
240.title: To Felt

241.html: value := utils.FromFelt(felt)
241.title: From Felt

243.html: isValid := utils.IsValidBigInt(value)
243.title: Is Valid Big Int

244.html: isValid := utils.IsValidFelt(value)
244.title: Is Valid Felt

245.html: isValid := utils.IsValidUint256(value)
245.title: Is Valid Uint256

247.html: result := utils.AddBigInts(a, b)
247.title: Add Big Ints

248.html: result := utils.SubBigInts(a, b)
248.title: Sub Big Ints

249.html: result := utils.MulBigInts(a, b)
249.title: Mul Big Ints

250.html: result := utils.DivBigInts(a, b)
250.title: Div Big Ints

251.html:
// Convert to big int
bigInt := utils.ToBigInt("123")
 
// Convert from big int
value := utils.FromBigInt(bigInt)
 
// Convert to felt
felt := utils.ToFelt("123")
 
// Convert from felt
value = utils.FromFelt(felt)
 
// Validate big int
isValid := utils.IsValidBigInt("123")
 
// Validate felt
isValid = utils.IsValidFelt("123")
 
// Validate uint256
isValid = utils.IsValidUint256("123")
 
// Add big ints
result := utils.AddBigInts("123", "456")
 
// Sub big ints
result = utils.SubBigInts("123", "456")
 
// Mul big ints
result = utils.MulBigInts("123", "456")
 
// Div big ints
result = utils.DivBigInts("123", "456")
251.title: Example Usage
